html:
The Day Ahead is an email and PDF publication that includes the day's major stories and events, analyses and other features. To receive The Day Ahead, Eikon users can register at DAY/US. Thomson One users can register at RT/DAY/US. All times in ET/GMT

ON MONDAY


U.S. President Joe Biden is scheduled to host a bipartisan bill-signing ceremony for his Bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act.


Amazon.com Inc is expected to reach a deal with Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc to sell virtual doctor services to the hotel chain's staff and corporate employees, in a boost for the online retailer's nascent healthcare business.


Lawyers for two Ohio counties and pharmacy chain operators CVS Health Corp, Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc and Walmart Inc are expected to deliver closing arguments in the first trial nationally in lawsuits accusing the companies of fueling the U.S. opioid epidemic. The counties accuse the pharmacy operators of failing to prevent addictive painkillers from being diverted for illicit uses, resulting in an oversupply of opioids in their communities.


The state of Washington is slated to take the three largest U.S. drug distributors to trial over allegations they fueled the country's deadly opioid epidemic. Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson has opted to take the case to trial after arguing that a proposal by McKesson Corp, AmersourceBergen and Cardinal Health Inc to pay $21 billion to settle the thousands of opioid lawsuits against them is "not nearly good enough."


WTO members are seeking to break a more than year-long deadlock over talks on waiving intellectual property rights for COVID-19 drugs and vaccines ahead of a major ministerial meeting later in November.


A federal judge in Tampa, Florida, is set to hear arguments by members of the U.S. military and by federal contractors who oppose the Biden Administration's COVID-19 vaccination mandate. The plaintiffs leading the class action said they want the judge to block the mandate because it does not allow for exceptions for religious opposition to vaccines.


A trial is expected to begin in San Francisco federal court on genetic biotech company Illumina Inc's claims that Chinese rival BGI's gene-sequencing products infringe five of its patents. The court already found that BGI directly infringed the patents. The jury will decide if the patents are valid, if BGI infringed willfully and/or induced others to infringe, and what damages Illumina may be entitled to. The parties have also been involved in several other legal disputes in the U.S. and worldwide. The trial is scheduled to end Nov. 23.


Former Johnson & Johnson talc supplier Imerys is likely to seek mediation in their respective Chapter 11 cases after Imerys failed to obtain the votes it needed for its proposed reorganization plan, which included a settlement with Cyprus over talc-related liabilities Imerys acquired when it purchased certain Cyprus assets in 1992. Both cases are before Judge Laurie Silverstein in Delaware.


Canada's manufacturing sales and wholesale trade data for September are on the economic schedule. Manufacturing sales is likley to have slipped 3% compared with a 0.5% rise in the previous month. Wholesale trade data for September is expected to have risen 1.1% from 0.3% in the earlier month.


LIVECHAT-REUTERS GLOBAL MARKETS FORUM

Even as the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow drafts "cover texts," including provisions to phase out coal, end fossil fuel subsidies and set up rules on global carbon offsets, etc., to "keep 1.5 alive" and implement the Paris climate accord, the Reuters Global Markets Forum brings together a special line-up of guests to discuss how these climate change goals will get funded, what the Net Zero Standard for Oil and Gas – the required standards to help discern how energy companies are seeking to tackle climate change - will look like, and other burning questions like who will pay to clean up the fossil fuel industry, including dismantling oil and gas facilities. Join us on the Reuters Global Markets Forum for discussions on the COP26 climate summit with Philip Gass, transitions and energy program lead at IISD (0400/0900) and Margret Trilli, CEO & CIO at ImpactAssets (1300/1800). To join the discussions, click here.



REST OF THE WEEK


U.S. retail giant Walmart Inc is expected to post a slight rise in third-quarter sales on Tuesday, benefiting from consumers doing their early Christmas shopping as a battle with supply chain problems deepens. Investors and analysts will be on the lookout for what Walmart executives will have to say about the all-important holiday season and how the company will be able to manage surging costs while keeping up with record demand. On the same day, Home Depot Inc is expected to report a rise in third-quarter same-store sales, helped by sustained demand for building materials and tools from professional contractors. Wall Street will be paying close attention to the company's profit margins as it spends heavily to counter supply chain disruptions and get products on store shelves in time for the holiday season. On Wednesday, Lowe's Companies Inc is expected to report a dip in third-quarter sales as demand from the company's core base of do-it-yourself home improvement customers slows. Wall Street will also be paying close attention to the company's profit margins as, like rival Home Depot, it spends heavily to counter supply chain disruptions.


On Thursday, Macy's Inc is expected to report a jump in third-quarter sales as customers return to stores after last year's pandemic restrictions, but investors will be more focused on the company's holiday season forecast as global supply chain disruptions threaten to create a shortage of products on store shelves. Separately, Kohl's Corp is expected to report a rise in third-quarter sales, but, as for rival Macy's, investors will be more focused on the company's comments around holiday season supply as global freight bottlenecks create shortages across industries, especially in apparel. On Wednesday, TJX Cos Inc is expected to post an increase in third-quarter revenue, as people buy more affordable clothing. Investors will look out for the off-price chain's comments on current inventory levels, potential price increases and the impact of higher freight and raw material costs on its margins.


On the U.S. economic tap, the Commerce Department, on Tuesday, is expected to report retail sales advanced 1.1% in October, after rising 0.7% in the previous month. Core retail sales likely rose 0.8%. A report by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday is expected to show industrial production increased 0.7% in October, after a fall of 1.3% in September. Manufacturing output likely jumped 0.8% in October, after dropping 0.7% in the previous month. Capacity utilization is expected to have risen 75.7% in October. Import prices likely rose 1.0% and export prices advanced 0.9% in October, the Labor Department is expected to report on Tuesday. On Wednesday, the Commerce Department is expected to report housing starts rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.580 million units in October from 1.555 million units in the month before. Building permits likely advanced to 1.630 million units in October from 1.586 million units in September. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index, on Tuesday, is likely to remain unchanged at 80 in November. On Thursday, the Labor Department is expected to report initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell 7,000 to a seasonally adjusted 260,000 for the week ended Nov. 13. The Commerce Department, on Tuesday, is expected to report business inventories it is likley to have inched up to 0.7% from 0.6% in September.


U.S. President Joe Biden is scheduled to travel to Woodstock, N.H., on Tuesday, to discuss a Bipartisan Infrastructure Deal.


On Tuesday, Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic and Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Thomas Barkin are scheduled to participate virtually in a panel before the Federal Reserve Racism and the Economy: Focus on Financial Services event. Bostic, on Wednesday, is likely to give closing remarks virtually before the Federal Reserve Community Development Research Seminar Series event. Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker is set to speak virtually on "Fintech and Financial Inclusion" before the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia Fifth Annual Fintech Conference on Tuesday. On Wednesday, Federal Reserve Bank President Loretta Mester is set to give introductory remarks before virtual 2021 Financial Stability Conference, "Planning for Surprises, Learning from Crises" organized by the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and the Office of Financial Research. On the same day, Federal Reserve Board Governor Christopher Waller is likely to give "Thoughts on Stablecoins" before virtual 2021 Financial Stability Conference, "Planning for Surprises, Learning from Crises" organized by the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and the Office of Financial Research. Waller is expected to speak on the economic outlook before the Center for Financial Stability Event on Friday. Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Charles Evans, on Wednesday, is scheduled to speak about current economic conditions and monetary policy in a moderated Q&A with Mid-Size Bank Coalition of America. On Thursday, Evans is set to discuss current economic conditions and monetary policy in a moderated Q&A with 2021 BKD Financial Services Symposium. On Wednesday, Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams is expected to give virtual keynote, while Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly is set to participate in a fireside chat virtually before the 2021 U.S. Treasury Market Conference co-organized by the Federal Reserve System and on Thursday, Daly is scheduled to participate in virtual Fed Listens 2021: Pandemic Recovery and the role of Care Work event. On Tuesday, Daly is expected to speak before the Commonwealth Club, San Francisco hybrid event. On Thursday, Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams is expected to participate in "Fireside Chat: The New Federal Reserve and ECB Strategies – Implications for Monetary Policy" before virtual Transatlantic Economic Policy Responses to the Pandemic and the Road to Recovery event. Federal Reserve Vice Chair Richard Clarida, on Friday, is expected to speak on "Perspectives on Global Monetary Policy Coordination, Cooperation, and Correlation" before virtual Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Asia Economic Policy Conference.


On Thursday, U.S. President Joe Biden is expected to host Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at the White House. This meeting is the first North American Leaders' Summit since 2016, the White House says, and focuses on COVID-19, competitiveness, migration and growth.


The World Trade Organization is set to issue its annual World Trade Report on Tuesday. This year, the report will be centered on resilience of global trade in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic and more intense natural and man-made disasters.


The World Health Organization's Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on immunisation is expected hold a closed-door meeting to review the need for COVID-19 booster shots on Thursday.


U.S. President Joe Biden is scheduled to visit General Motors Co's Detroit-Hamtramck electric vehicle assembly plant on Wednesday.


On Wednesday, the latest IIF Global Debt Monitor "Confronting Climate Change and Policy Normalization" is expected to discuss the role of global debt markets in the transition to a low-carbon future and the implications of global policy normalization in a high-debt environment amid inflationary pressures and supply chain disruptions.


On Tuesday, Aetna Inc is expected to ask the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 3rd Circuit to seal information the healthcare company's reimbursement rates, negotiating strategies and contracts that was submitted as part of the Federal Trade Commissions suit challenging Thomas Jefferson University and Albert Einstein Healthcare Network's hospital merger. Aetna says the now public information could violate antitrust laws if it's shared between competitors.


A bankruptcy judge is expected to hear arguments on Tuesday over whether to hold the founder of New York real estate law firm Kossoff PLLC in civil contempt and incarcerate him if he continues defying court orders to cooperate.


Boeing Co's Managing Director of Regional Marketing Dave Schulte is expected to hold a briefing on outlook for the Oceania region on Tuesday.


U.S. oil refiner Citgo Petroleum Corp, on Wednesday, is expected to report results for the quarter ended Sept. 30 that reflect improving motor fuel demand and higher utilization at its three refineries. It swung to a slim, second-quarter profit on stronger fuel exports and a big contribution from its Lemont Ill refinery that processes cheap Canadian crude.


The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is set to hold its monthly virtual open meeting on Thursday. Items the commission will consider include whether it should stay its certification of the Jordan Cove LNG given an April decision by its developer Pembina Pipeline Corp to pause the project.


S&P on Thursday is scheduled to host a conference discussing the future of lending, ESG risks and the impact of new technology on lending. Bill Ackman is expected to speak at the conference.


On Thursday, North Carolina regulators are expected to hold a public hearing as part of the review process for Piedmont Lithium Inc's state mining permit application.


Los Angeles Auto Show confirms a strong return to LA Convention Center in November 2021 on Wednesday, with its press and trade days (AutoMobility LA) taking place Nov. 17-18, and its doors opening to consumers Nov. 19-28.


Lawrence Schembri, deputy governor of the Bank of Canada on Tuesday, is scheduled to give a speech on labor market uncertainties and monetary policy to the Canadian Association for Business Economics.


Canada's inflation figures for October are scheduled for release on Wednesday. Annual inflation is likley to have increased 4.6% compared with a 4.4% rise in September to reach its fastest clip since February 2003. Statistics Canada is expected to release retail sales data for September on Friday. Canadian retail sales is expected to have dropped to 1.7% after a 2.1% rise in August. Housing starts data for October is due on Tuesday. It is likely to have risen to 257,500 from 251,200 in the earlier month.




(Compiled by Nidhi C Sai in Bengaluru; Editing by Devika Syamnath)

(( Nidhi.CSai@thomsonreuters.com ;))
